dt: {bc}belief and trust in and loyalty to God
{bc}belief in the traditional {d_link|doctrines|doctrine} of a religion
{bc}firm belief in something for which there is no proof

dt.t: clinging to the {wi}faith{/wi} that her missing son would one day return

dt: {bc}something that is believed especially with strong conviction

pt: {sc}belief{/sc} {sc}faith{/sc} {sc}credence{/sc} {sc}credit{/sc} mean assent to the truth of something offered for acceptance. {sc}belief{/sc} may or may not imply certitude in the believer.

pt.t: my {it}belief{/it} that I had caught all the errors

pt: {sc}faith{/sc} almost always implies certitude even where there is no evidence or proof.
{sc}credence{/sc} suggests intellectual assent without implying anything about grounds for assent.

pt.t: a theory now given {it}credence{/it} by scientists

pt: {sc}credit{/sc} may imply assent on grounds other than direct proof.

pt.t: gave full {it}credit{/it} to the statement of a reputable witness

quotes.t: {qword}Faith{/qword} without doubt leads to moral arrogance, the eternal pratfall of the religiously convinced.
Nick wiped at the moustache of sweat droplets that was as much a part of his face as his eyes and nose and gave a shrug that indicated a certain lack of {qword}faith{/qword} in our judgment.

But while no one with a grain of sense trusted Miss Stephanie, Jem and I had considerable {qword}faith{/qword} in Miss Maudie. She had never told on us, had never played cat-and-mouse with us, she was not at all interested in our private lives. She was our friend.

et: Middle English {it}feith, fei,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}feit, feid, fei,{/it} going back to Latin {it}fidēs{/it} "trust, guarantee, proof, sincerity, loyalty, belief," going back to {it}*bhid-ēi-,{/it} noun derivative from zero-grade of an Indo-European verbal base {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}ei̯d{sup}h{/sup}-{/it} "entrust, trust," whence Latin {it}fīdere{/it} "to trust (in), have confidence (in)," {it}fīdus{/it} "faithful," Greek {it}peíthesthai{/it} "to obey, comply with, believe," {it}peíthein{/it} "to persuade, prevail upon," Albanian {it}be{/it} "oath," and probably Old Church Slavic{it} běždǫ, běditi{/it} "to compel, constrain," {it}běda{/it} "distress, need"

The English word is an early loan from medieval French, first attested in a homily fragment from the 12th century (see {it}feþ{/it} in {it}Dictionary of Old English{/it}); it appears to preserve the final interdental fricative generally lost in early Old French—a loss reflected in the more common Anglo-French form {it}fei{/it} (also loaned into Middle English—see {et_link|fay:2|fay:2}). Indo-European {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}ei̯d{sup}h{/sup}-{/it} is also usually claimed to be the source of Germanic {it}*bīðan-{/it} "to wait" (see {et_link|bide|bide}).
shortdef: allegiance to duty or a person : loyalty

dt: {bc}a method of treating diseases by prayer and exercise of faith in God

shortdef: a method of treating diseases by prayer and exercise of faith in God

dt: {bc}to accept (something) as true without proof or evidence that it is true

dt.t: I'm not willing to {it}take{/it} her statements {it}on faith{/it}.
I'll {it}accept{/it} it {it}on faith{/it} that he knows the truth.

shortdef: to accept (something) as true without proof or evidence that it is true

dt: {bc}something that is believed without being questioned or doubted

dt.t: For many it is an {it}article of faith{/it} that the economy will begin to improve soon.

shortdef: something that is believed without being questioned or doubted

dt: {bc}lack of honesty in dealing with other people

dt.t: She accused her landlord of {it}bad faith{/it} because he had promised to paint the apartment but never did it.

shortdef: lack of honesty in dealing with other people

dt: {bc}to stop supporting or being loyal to (someone) {bc}to betray (someone)

dt.t: He has accused the government of {it}breaking faith with{/it} its supporters.

shortdef: to stop supporting or being loyal to (someone) : to betray (someone)

dt: {bc}to begin to believe in God or develop strong religious beliefs

shortdef: to begin to believe in God or develop strong religious beliefs
